Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of mental retardation who has been admitted to the ICU with sepsis, respiratory failure, and bowel obstruction. The patient has been receiving treatment with vancomycin, cefepime, and fluconazole for sepsis, and has shown some improvement in his condition.

The patient's respiratory status is a concern, with persistent hypoxemic respiratory failure and limited ability to clear secretions due to his mental status. The patient is currently receiving CPAP/PSV ventilation and has had some improvement in his oxygenation.

The patient's bowel obstruction has been persistent, but has shown some improvement on CT scan.

The patient has had some laboratory abnormalities, including elevated white blood cell count, decreased hematocrit, and elevated lactate levels. He has also had some imaging abnormalities, including a CXR showing right lower lobe opacity.

The patient's plan of care includes ongoing treatment for sepsis, respiratory failure, and bowel obstruction. He will require continued close monitoring and management of his respiratory status, as well as ongoing treatment for his sepsis and bowel obstruction.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is a concern, and he may require ongoing ventilatory support to manage his respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, and may require ongoing treatment to manage his infection and prevent further complications.
* Bowel obstruction: The patient has a persistent bowel obstruction, and may require ongoing treatment to manage his symptoms and prevent further complications.
* Pneumonia: The patient has a CXR showing right lower lobe opacity, which may indicate pneumonia.
* DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to his prolonged immobility and may require prophylactic treatment.
* Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulcer due to his prolonged immobility and may require prophylactic treatment.
* VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP due to his prolonged immobility and may require prophylactic treatment.

Overall, the patient requires ongoing close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and promote recovery.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan: 84 year old nursing home resident with dementia,
   mental retardation, initially admitted with urosepsis and with
   development of hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, fecal impaction.
   .
   # Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure:  Likely secondary to increased
   abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia / pneumonitis from
   extubation reintubation.  Continues to have secretions which will be a
   barrier to extubation.
   - continue to see WBC trending down.
   - suction secretions, which are less
   - changed to PS 14/10, PEEP weaned down to 8.  Will calculate RSBI and
   try SBT.
   - continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc (day 6 of 8 day course)
   (day 1: Day 1 = [**8-3**]).  Vanc changed to q24h bc vanc level of 29.
   Check vanc level.
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - continue GI decompression with NGT and rectal tube.
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   # sepsis: likely Gu source given positive UA, and patient
s history of
   urosepsis during prior ICU stay.  GI source is also likely as patient
   has distended colon, it is possible that patient becomes transiently
   bacteremic through distended bowel loops.  Pulmonary infection could
   play a role as well, but the pneumonia likely occurred during
   intubation as a result of aspiration in the long intubation process.
   - WBC continuing to trend down
   - continue fluconazole (day 6 of 14 day course) (day 1: [**8-2**])
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - f/u blood culture
   - fluid boluses prn to maintain MAP>65, CVP>[**9-1**], ScvO2 >70%
   - fu ID recs recs
   - tylenol for fever
   - culutre if spikes
   .
   # Colonic dilation: improving on imaging, stable on clinical exam. no
   evidence of a mechanical obstruction per radiology, likely related to a
   stool ball in his sigmoid colon vs. ileus. Per surgery any surgical
   intervention will likely involve a total colectomy. Per GI
   sigmoidoscopy will not be able to relieve an obstruction related to
   stool.
   -per HCP, no aggressive intervention: pursue conservative management
   -NGT and rectal tube in 30 cm for decompression
   -d/c enemas per GI
   - continue lactulose
   -continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc for 8 days (day 1: Day 1 =
   [**8-3**])
   -GI and gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] have signed off
   -electrolyte repletion
   -follow lactate
   .
   # Anemia: hct has been trending down during the past several days.
   Baseline hct 37-39. no evidence of bleeding. Could be contributed by
   dilutional effect and anemia of inflammation (anemia of chronic
   disease)
   - guaiac stool
   - transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #DM: continue glargine and sliding scale insulin.
   .
   # Neuro status: On morning rounds,not alert enough to further assess
   neuro status, but did grimace to pain in all 4 extremities.
   - re-assess neuro status when pt is more alert
   .
   #Hypothyroid - continue synthroid (now IV dose)
   .
   #h/o seizure disorder - continue dilantin, phenobarbital (IV).
   - check dilantin level
   .
   #osteoporosis - continue calcium and vitamin d
   .
   #Goals of care: Confirmed with HCP [**Name (NI) 792**] [**Name (NI) 8911**], pt is DNR. If
   medically optimized and pt is extubated, he would be DNI at that time,
   and comfort measures only if not tolerating after extubation.  Should
   he self extubate, will re-intubate.
   .
   #Anterior extraperitoneal bladder perforation: not a current active
   issue as per urology was likely a small perforation and self
   contained.  Per radiology no perforation was seen.
   -maintain foley
   -call urology if foley requires flushing
   .
   #Hypernatremia: resolved.
   -continue to monitor
   .
   #Acute renal failure
 resolved.  likely pre-renal in the setting of
   sepsis and hypotension
   - continue sepsis treatment
   - maintain BP with IVF
   -send urine lytes and urinalysis if creatinine worsens
   -renally dose meds

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 84-year-old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation, initially admitted with urosepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, and fecal impaction. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.6°C (99.6°F)
* Heart rate: 87 bpm (normal range: 77-100 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 98/55 mmHg (normal range: 71-122/58-108 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute (normal range: 13-30 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 95%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient has a history of:

* Urosepsis during a prior ICU stay
* Dementia and mental retardation
* Seizure disorder
* Hypothyroidism
* Osteoporosis
* Anterior extraperitoneal bladder perforation (resolved)

The patient is currently receiving:

* Mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 404 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O
* Antibiotics: cefepime, vancomycin, and fluconazole
* Antifungal therapy: fluconazole
* Antiviral therapy: none
* Sedation: midazolam and fentanyl
* Analgesia: fentanyl
* Anti-seizure medication: phenytoin
* Thyroid replacement therapy: synthroid (IV dose)
* Calcium and vitamin D supplementation
* Insulin therapy: glargine and sliding scale insulin

The patient has the following laboratory results:

* White blood cell count: 18.4 K/uL (normal range: 4-11 K/uL)
* Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL (normal range: 12-16 g/dL)
* Platelet count: 22 K/uL (normal range: 150-450 K/uL)
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.1 mg/dL)
* Blood urea nitrogen: 196 mg/dL (normal range: 7-18 mg/dL)
* Electrolytes: sodium 112 mEq/L (normal range: 135-145 mEq/L), potassium 3.9 mEq/L (normal range: 3.5-5.5 mEq/L), and chloride 25.1% (normal range: 20-30%)

The patient's medical complications include:

* Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Colonic dilation
* Anemia
* Hypernatremia (resolved)
* Acute renal failure (resolved)

The patient's goals of care are:

* To be medically optimized and extubated
* To be DNI if extubated and not tolerating
* To receive comfort measures only if not tolerating after extubation
* To avoid self-extubation and re-intubation if necessary

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia
* Aspiration
* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury
* Electrolyte imbalances
* Hyperglycemia
* Hypoglycemia
* Seizures
* Hypothyroidism
* Osteoporosis-related fractures
* Anterior extraperitoneal bladder perforation (re-occurrence)
* Colonic obstruction
* Anemia-related complications
* Hypernatremia (re-occurrence)

Based on the patient's history, laboratory results, and medical complications, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition closely to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old nursing home resident with a history of dementia, mental retardation, and urosepsis, currently admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic acute respiratory failure, sepsis, colonic dilation, anemia, diabetes mellitus, and other comorbidities.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.6°C (99.6°F)
* Heart rate: 87 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 98/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 95%
* Height: 67 inches
* Weight: Not reported

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 18.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 22 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 24 mg/dL
* Glucose: 167 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: Normal
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.3 g/dL
* LDH: 181 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.7 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.0 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.0 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure
* Sepsis (likely of gastrointestinal origin)
* Colonic dilation (improving on imaging, stable on clinical exam)
* Anemia (likely due to dilutional effect and anemia of inflammation)
* Diabetes mellitus
* Hypothyroidism
* History of seizure disorder
* Osteoporosis

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Broad-spectrum antibiotics (cefepime and vancomycin) for 8 days
* Suctioning of secretions
* GI decompression with NGT and rectal tube
* Fluid boluses as needed to maintain MAP > 65, CVP > 9, and ScvO2 > 70%
* Electrolyte repletion
* Follow-up blood culture
* Tylenol for fever
* Cultures if spikes

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia or pneumonitis from aspiration or extubation
* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction (e.g., acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome)
* Colonic perforation or obstruction
* Anemia-related complications (e.g., heart failure, decreased oxygen delivery to tissues)
* Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia
* Hypothyroidism-related complications (e.g., fatigue, cold intolerance)
* Osteoporosis-related complications (e.g., fractures, decreased mobility)
* Seizure disorder-related complications (e.g., seizure activity, altered mental status)

The patient's goals of care are:

* Medical optimization
* Extubation
* Comfort measures only if not tolerating after extubation
* DNR (do not resuscitate) status, with the option to become DNI (do not intubate) if extubated.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of mental retardation, currently experiencing significant and persistent hypoxemic respiratory failure, primarily due to mental status, weakness, and high-volume secretions. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9°C (100.2°F), heart rate of 83 beats per minute, blood pressure of 112/42 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on 50% FiO2. The patient's respiratory support includes a CPAP/PSV ventilator mode with a tidal volume of 369 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 26 cmH2O, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia (Hb 8.0 g/dL), leukocytosis (WBC 18.4), and elevated lactate levels (0.8 mmol/L). The patient's imaging studies, including a chest X-ray, are unremarkable.

The patient's medical conditions include respiratory failure, abdominal distention, and sepsis. The patient is receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole, for the treatment of sepsis. The patient is also receiving prophylactic anticoagulation with heparin sodium.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to the prolonged duration of mechanical ventilation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if the patient's secretions are not managed effectively or if the patient develops a respiratory infection.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress to septic shock if the patient's underlying condition is not managed effectively.
4. Abdominal distention: The patient's abdominal distention may worsen if the patient's bowel obstruction is not managed effectively.
5. Constipation: The patient's constipation may worsen if the patient's bowel function is not managed effectively.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen if the patient's glucose levels are not managed effectively.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if the patient's underlying condition is not managed effectively.
8. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may worsen if the patient's underlying condition is not managed effectively.

To manage these potential complications, the patient's care team should continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies closely. The patient's respiratory support should be adjusted as needed to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation. The patient's antibiotics should be continued as directed, and the patient's bowel function should be managed effectively to prevent constipation. The patient's glucose levels should be monitored closely and managed effectively to prevent hyperglycemia. The patient's anemia and leukocytosis should be managed effectively to prevent worsening of these conditions.

   # Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure:  Likely secondary to increased
   abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia / pneumonitis from
   extubation reintubation.  Continues to have secretions which will be a
   barrier to extubation.

   today and try SBT.
   - continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc (day 6 of 8 day course)
   (day 1: Day 1 = [**8-3**]).  Vanc changed to q24h bc vanc level of 29.
   Check vanc level.

   - continue GI decompression with NGT and rectal tube.
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   # sepsis: likely Gu source given positive UA, and patient
s history of
   urosepsis during prior ICU stay.  GI source is also likely as patient
   has distended colon, it is possible that patient becomes transiently
   bacteremic through distended bowel loops.  Pulmonary infection could
   play a role as well, but the pneumonia likely occurred during
   intubation as a result of aspiration in the long intubation process.
   - WBC continuing to trend down
   - continue fluconazole (day 6 of 14 day course) (day 1: [**8-2**])
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - f/u blood culture
   - fluid boluses prn to maintain MAP>65, CVP>[**9-1**], ScvO2 >70%
   - fu ID recs recs
   - tylenol for fever
   - culutre if spikes
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation, who was initially admitted with urosepsis and developed hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, and fecal impaction. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has hypoxemic acute respiratory failure likely secondary to increased abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia/pneumonitis from extubation reintubation. The patient continues to have secretions, which will be a barrier to extubation. The respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV with PEEP 8 cmH2O, FiO2 50%, and RSBI 121.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's blood pressure is 110/67 mmHg, heart rate is 92 bpm, and oxygen saturation is 95%. The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is not specified.
* Neurological: The patient is drowsy, arousable, and oriented x1. The patient's neuro status is difficult to assess due to decreased sedation, but the patient did grimace to pain in all four extremities.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has colonic dilation, which is improving on imaging and stable on clinical exam. The patient has a stool ball in his sigmoid colon, and surgery may involve a total colectomy. The patient is receiving lactulose and NGT and rectal tube decompression.
* Infection: The patient has sepsis likely from a gastrointestinal source, and the patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient's white blood cell count is trending down.
* Renal: The patient has acute renal failure, which is likely pre-renal in the setting of sepsis and hypotension. The patient's creatinine is not specified.
* Endocrine: The patient has hypothyroidism, and the patient is receiving thyroid hormone replacement therapy. The patient also has diabetes, and the patient is receiving insulin therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and the patient may require further interventions to improve oxygenation and ventilation.
* Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, and the patient may require further antibiotics and supportive care to manage the infection.
* Colonic perforation: The patient has colonic dilation, and the patient may be at risk for colonic perforation, which can lead to peritonitis and sepsis.
* Neurological decline: The patient's neurological status is difficult to assess due to decreased sedation, and the patient may require further evaluation and management to prevent neurological decline.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a stool ball in his sigmoid colon, and the patient may be at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to anemia and hypovolemic shock.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, and the patient may require further supportive care and interventions to manage the condition.

The patient's goals of care are to be medically optimized and extubated, and if the patient is unable to tolerate extubation, the patient will receive comfort measures only. The patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient, an 84-year-old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation, and a history of urosepsis, is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with hypoxemic acute respiratory failure, sepsis, and colonic dilation. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 92 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 110/67 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 95%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 16.0 x 10^9/L ( trending down)
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 505 x 10^9/L
* Blood urea nitrogen: 193 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.9 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Colonic dilation
* Anemia
* Diabetes mellitus
* Hypothyroidism
* History of seizure disorder
* Osteoporosis

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation
* Broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage with cefepime and vancomycin
* Suctioning of secretions
* GI decompression with nasogastric tube and rectal tube
* Fluid boluses to maintain mean arterial pressure >65 mmHg, central venous pressure >9 mmHg, and mixed venous oxygen saturation >70%
* Electrolyte repletion
* Follow-up of lactate levels
* Continued lactulose therapy
* Monitoring of blood cultures
* Consideration of sigmoidoscopy or total colectomy for colonic dilation

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Colonic perforation or obstruction
* Anemia-related complications
* Hyperglycemia
* Hypothyroidism-related complications
* Seizure disorder-related complications
* Osteoporosis-related complications

The patient's goals of care have been confirmed as DNR, with the option to transition to DNI if extubated and tolerating. If the patient self-extubates, re-intubation will be performed.

   Assessment and Plan: 84 year old nursing home resident with dementia,
   mental retardation, initially admitted with urosepsis and with
   development of hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, fecal impaction.
   .
   # Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure:  Likely secondary to increased
   abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia / pneumonitis from
   extubation reintubation.  Continues to have secretions which will be a
   barrier to extubation.
   - continue to see WBC trending down.
   - suction secretions, which are less
   - changed to PS 14/8, PEEP weaned down to 8.  Will calculate RSBI again
   today and try SBT.
   - continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc (day 6 of 8 day course)
   (day 1: Day 1 = [**8-3**]).  Vanc changed to q24h bc vanc level of 29.
   Check vanc level.
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - continue GI decompression with NGT and rectal tube.
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   # sepsis: likely Gu source given positive UA, and patient
s history of
   urosepsis during prior ICU stay.  GI source is also likely as patient
   has distended colon, it is possible that patient becomes transiently
   bacteremic through distended bowel loops.  Pulmonary infection could
   play a role as well, but the pneumonia likely occurred during
   intubation as a result of aspiration in the long intubation process.
   - WBC continuing to trend down
   - continue fluconazole (day 6 of 14 day course) (day 1: [**8-2**])
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - f/u blood culture
   - fluid boluses prn to maintain MAP>65, CVP>[**9-1**], ScvO2 >70%
   - fu ID recs recs
   - tylenol for fever
   - culutre if spikes
   .
   # Colonic dilation: improving on imaging, stable on clinical exam. no
   evidence of a mechanical obstruction per radiology, likely related to a
   stool ball in his sigmoid colon vs. ileus. Per surgery any surgical
   intervention will likely involve a total colectomy. Per GI
   sigmoidoscopy will not be able to relieve an obstruction related to
   stool.
   -per HCP, no aggressive intervention: pursue conservative management
   -NGT and rectal tube in 30 cm for decompression
   -d/c enemas per GI
   - continue lactulose
   -continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc for 8 days (day 1: Day 1 =
   [**8-3**])
   -GI and gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] have signed off
   -electrolyte repletion
   -follow lactate
   .
   # Anemia: hct has been trending down during the past several days.
   Baseline hct 37-39. no evidence of bleeding. Could be contributed by
   dilutional effect and anemia of inflammation (anemia of chronic
   disease)
   - guaiac stool
   - transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #DM: continue glargine and sliding scale insulin.
   .
   # Neuro status: On morning rounds,not alert enough to further assess
   neuro status, but did grimace to pain in all 4 extremities.
   - re-assess neuro status when pt is more alert
   .
   #Hypothyroid - continue synthroid (now IV dose)
   .
   #h/o seizure disorder - continue dilantin, phenobarbital (IV).
   - check dilantin level
   .
   #osteoporosis - continue calcium and vitamin d
   .
   #Goals of care: Confirmed with HCP [**Name (NI) 792**] [**Name (NI) 8911**], pt is DNR. If
   medically optimized and pt is extubated, he would be DNI at that time,
   and comfort measures only if not tolerating after extubation.  Should
   he self extubate, will re-intubate.
   .
   #Anterior extraperitoneal bladder perforation: not a current active
   issue as per urology was likely a small perforation and self
   contained.  Per radiology no perforation was seen.
   -maintain foley
   -call urology if foley requires flushing
   .
   #Hypernatremia: resolved.
   -continue to monitor
   .
   #Acute renal failure
 resolved.  likely pre-renal in the setting of
   sepsis and hypotension
   - continue sepsis treatment
   - maintain BP with IVF
   -send urine lytes and urinalysis if creatinine worsens
   -renally dose meds

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current health status as follows:

* The patient is an 84-year-old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation, and a history of urosepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
* The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a PEEP of 8 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%.
* The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure of 110/67 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute.
* The patient's laboratory results show trending down WBC count, stable hemoglobin, and stable electrolyte levels.
* The patient's abdomen is massively distended, and they have a Foley catheter in place.
* The patient has a history of sepsis, anemia, diabetes, hypothyroidism, seizure disorder, and osteoporosis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of pneumonia, which can lead to further respiratory failure and potential sepsis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's current sepsis treatment and positive blood cultures suggest a high risk of sepsis progression, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Colonic dilation: The patient's distended colon and history of fecal impaction increase the risk of colonic perforation, which can lead to peritonitis and sepsis.
4. Anemia: The patient's declining hemoglobin levels and history of anemia increase the risk of further anemia, which can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's history of diabetes and use of insulin increase the risk of hyperglycemia, which can lead to further complications such as ketoacidosis and coma.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's history of hypothyroidism and current treatment with thyroid hormone replacement therapy increase the risk of hypothyroidism-related complications, such as myxedema coma.
7. Seizure disorder: The patient's history of seizure disorder and current treatment with anticonvulsant medications increase the risk of seizure recurrence, which can lead to further complications such as brain damage and respiratory failure.
8. Osteoporosis: The patient's history of osteoporosis and current treatment with calcium and vitamin D supplements increase the risk of osteoporosis-related complications, such as vertebral compression fractures and hip fractures.

To address these potential complications, the patient's care team should continue to monitor their vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status, and adjust their treatment plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, who is intubated and sedated in the ICU. The patient has been diagnosed with urosepsis, impaction, and respiratory failure, with a history of pneumonia (pna) and effusions. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and pain management medications.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 92 bpm (81-97 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 110/67 mmHg (85-159/104 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 24 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Intubation
* Sedation
* Decreased lung sounds at the bases
* Distended abdomen
* No edema in the extremities

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count: 16.0-11.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 505 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.3-1.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 193 mg/dL
* Glucose: 180-193 mg/dL
* Other laboratory results include:

* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST, and Alk Phos)
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
* Elevated calcium (Ca++), magnesium (Mg++), and phosphate (PO4) levels
* Elevated albumin and decreased lipase levels
* Decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit (Hct)

The patient's radiology results include a CXR showing volume loss on the left side and hazy right base.

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning the patient off the ventilator as tolerated
* Continuing antibiotics for urosepsis and bacteremia
* Continuing antifungal therapy for funguria
* Continuing rectal tube and TPN for colonic distension
* Managing diabetes with insulin
* Monitoring for and prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to continued pneumonia and effusions
* Sepsis and bacteremia due to urosepsis and funguria
* Colonic distension and impaction due to constipation
* Worsening of diabetes and hyperglycemia
* Development of DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Hemodynamic instability due to sepsis and hypovolemia
* Renal failure due to prolonged use of antibiotics and other medications
* Cardiovascular instability due to sepsis and hypovolemia

* Heart rate: 92 beats per minute (bpm) with a range of 81-97 bpm
* Blood pressure: 110/67 mmHg with a range of 80/39-159/104 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute with a range of 16-27 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient has received multiple medications, including antibiotics (Metronidazole, Vancomycin, and Cefipime), antifungal medication (Fluconazole), sedatives (Fentanyl and Midazolam), and anticonvulsant medication (Dilantin). They are also receiving nutrition through Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) with lipids.

The patient has several lab results, including:

* White blood cell count: 16.0-11.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 505 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.3-1.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 193 mg/dL
* Glucose: 180-196 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Sodium 143 mEq/L, Potassium 112 mEq/L, Chloride 26 mEq/L, Bicarbonate 25.4%
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 237 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.9 mg/dL

The patient has several diagnoses, including:

* Constipation (obstipation)
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)

The patient is receiving ICU care, including mechanical ventilation, and is being treated with prophylactic medications for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and they are receiving mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of respiratory failure worsening or developing respiratory acidosis.
* Sepsis: The patient has sepsis without organ dysfunction, which can progress to septic shock or organ dysfunction if not managed promptly and effectively.
* Constipation: The patient has constipation, which can lead to bowel obstruction, perforation, or hemorrhage if not managed promptly and effectively.
* Infection: The patient has received multiple antibiotics, which can increase the risk of antibiotic resistance and superinfection.
* Fluid overload: The patient has received significant amounts of fluid, which can lead to fluid overload and cardiac compromise.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or neurological deficits.
* Renal dysfunction: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, which can indicate renal dysfunction or failure.
* Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, which can indicate hepatic dysfunction or failure.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to monitor their vital signs, lab results, and medication regimen closely to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of urosepsis, impaction, and respiratory failure. The patient has been receiving multiple antibiotics, including metronidazole, vancomycin, cefipime, and fluconazole, as well as vasopressors, sedatives, and analgesics.

Physiological parameters:

* Vital signs: Temperature 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate 92 bpm, blood pressure 110/67 mmHg, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving vasopressors to maintain blood pressure.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 2,537 mL of fluids, with 1,945 mL of urine output.
* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 440 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O.

Laboratory results:

* Complete Blood Count (CBC): White blood cell count 16.0, hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL, and platelet count 505 K/uL.
* Electrolyte panel: Sodium 143 mEq/L, potassium 4.0 mEq/L, chloride 25.4%, and bicarbonate 26 mEq/L.
* Blood gases: Arterial blood gas (ABG) results are not provided, but the patient has a respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.26.
* Liver enzymes: Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 31 IU/L, aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 44 IU/L, and alkaline phosphatase (Alk Phos) 91 IU/L.
* Renal function: Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) not provided.

Radiology:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): The patient has volume loss in the left lung and hazy right base.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and hypoxemia may worsen if not adequately managed.
* Sepsis: The patient's urosepsis may lead to further organ dysfunction and failure.
* Constipation: The patient's impaction and constipation may worsen if not managed effectively.
* Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient is at risk for VTE due to immobility and prolonged hospitalization.
* Stress ulcer: The patient's critical illness may lead to stress ulceration.
* Catheter-related infections: The patient's central lines and urinary catheter may be at risk for infection.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to closely monitor their physiological parameters, laboratory results, and radiological findings to identify any potential complications and adjust management accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities and complications. The patient's chief complaint is urosepsis, impaction, and respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 92 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/67 mmHg. The patient is intubated and sedated, with a respiratory rate of 24 inspirations per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 98% on 50% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and lactate dehydrogenase levels, indicating possible sepsis. The patient's blood cultures are positive for bacteria, and the patient is receiving antibiotics. The patient's creatinine and potassium levels are elevated, indicating possible kidney dysfunction.

The patient's imaging studies show volume loss on the left side and hazy right base on the chest X-ray.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is to be weaned off the ventilator as tolerated, and antibiotics will be continued.
2. Urosepsis: The patient will continue to receive antibiotics.
3. Funguria: The patient will continue to receive fluconazole.
4. Colonic distension: The patient will continue to receive rectal tube and total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
5. Diabetes mellitus: The patient will receive insulin.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's elevated lactate dehydrogenase level and positive blood cultures indicate possible sepsis-related organ dysfunction.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can lead to further complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia and lung injury.
3. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's elevated creatinine and potassium levels indicate possible kidney dysfunction, which can lead to further complications such as acute kidney injury and electrolyte imbalances.
4. Infection: The patient's positive blood cultures indicate possible infection, which can lead to further complications such as sepsis and organ dysfunction.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's colonic distension and positive blood cultures indicate possible gastrointestinal complications, which can lead to further complications such as perforation and sepsis.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities and complications. The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve their clinical outcomes.

The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, with a respiratory rate of 29 inspirations per minute and a SpO2 of 94%.

3. Constipation: The patient's constipation is being treated with laxatives, but there is a risk of worsening constipation if the patient's underlying condition is not improving.
4. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient is at risk of developing VTE due to their prolonged immobility and underlying medical condition.
5. Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk of developing stress ulcers due to their critical illness and treatment with corticosteroids.
6. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk of developing VAP due to their prolonged use of mechanical ventilation.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infection due to their prolonged immobility and underlying medical condition.
8. Organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics and antifungals are important steps in managing the condition. However, there is a risk of organ dysfunction, particularly if the patient's underlying condition is not improving.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple medical conditions. Here is a summary of the patient's current status:

1. Respiratory status: The patient is mechanically ventilated with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 338 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 20 cmH2O, and a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 94%, and the partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is 242 mmHg.
2. Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is 123/47 mmHg, with a heart rate of 97 beats per minute. The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is not reported.
3. Laboratory results:
	* White blood cell count (WBC): 14.3-11.6 x10^9/L
	* Hematocrit (Hct): 26.3-24.3%
	* Platelet count (Plt): 396-536 x10^9/L
	* Creatinine (Cr): 1.1-0.9 mg/dL
	* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): not reported
	* Electrolytes: sodium (Na): 143 mmol/L, potassium (K): 4.7 mmol/L, chloride (Cl): 112 mmol/L, bicarbonate (HCO3-): 26 mmol/L
4. Infections:
	* Urinary tract infection (UTI): The patient is receiving antibiotics.
	* Funguria: The patient is receiving fluconazole.
	* Bacteremia: The patient is receiving antibiotics.
5. Other medical conditions:
	* Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated.
	* Colonic distension: The patient has a rectal tube and is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
	* Diabetes mellitus (DM): The patient is receiving insulin.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
2. Infections: The patient has multiple infections, including UTI, funguria, and bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Colonic distension: The patient's colonic distension can lead to complications such as bowel perforation, peritonitis, and sepsis.
4. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's DM can lead to hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, and other complications.
5. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and there is a risk of further hypotension or hypertension.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation profile is abnormal, which can increase the risk of bleeding complications.
7. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which can indicate renal dysfunction or failure.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac status is critical, and there is a risk of further cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, or cardiac arrest.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure, pna, effusions, and atelectasis. They are intubated and sedated, with a stable CXR showing RLL infiltrate and volume loss in the LLL. The patient has a UTI and bacteremia, which is being treated with antibiotics. They also have funguria, which is being treated with fluconazole for two weeks. The patient has colonic distension, which is being managed with a rectal tube and TPN. Additionally, the patient has diabetes mellitus and is being treated with insulin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and they are at risk for further deterioration. Close monitoring of their respiratory status and adjustment of their ventilation settings are necessary to prevent further decline.
2. UTI and bacteremia: The patient's UTI and bacteremia need to be closely monitored, and antibiotic therapy should be adjusted as necessary to prevent the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
3. Funguria: The patient's funguria needs to be monitored, and fluconazole therapy should be continued for the full two-week course to prevent relapse.
4. Colonic distension: The patient's colonic distension needs to be managed carefully to prevent further complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
5. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus needs to be closely monitored, and insulin therapy should be adjusted as necessary to maintain good glycemic control.
6. DVT prophylaxis: The patient is at risk for developing DVT, and prophylactic measures should be taken to prevent this complication.
7. Stress ulcer prophylaxis: The patient is at risk for developing stress ulcers, and prophylactic measures should be taken to prevent this complication.
8. VAP prophylaxis: The patient is at risk for developing VAP, and prophylactic measures should be taken to prevent this complication.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 8 cmH2O. The patient's SpO2 is 94% and ABG results indicate a pH of 7.39, PaO2 of 242, and PaCO2 of 47.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is 123/47 mmHg, with a heart rate of 97 bpm and sinus rhythm. The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is not mentioned in the note, but the fluid balance suggests a slight positive balance.
* Renal function: The patient's creatinine level is within normal limits, and the blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is not mentioned.
* Liver function: The patient's liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, are mildly elevated.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has an elevated potassium level (5.36 mEq/L) and a decreased calcium level (8.3 mg/dL).
* Infectious disease: The patient has a suspected urinary tract infection (UTI) and bacteremia, for which antibiotics are being completed. The patient also has funguria, for which fluconazole is being continued for two weeks.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has colonic distension, for which a rectal tube and total parenteral nutrition (TPN) are being continued.
* Endocrine status: The patient has diabetes mellitus (DM), for which insulin is being administered.

Potential medical complications that may arise based on the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and weaning from mechanical ventilation may be challenging.
* Sepsis: The patient's suspected UTI and bacteremia may lead to sepsis, which could worsen the patient's condition.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's elevated potassium level and decreased calcium level may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's colonic distension and constipation may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Wound infection: The patient's skin integrity is compromised due to the presence of tubes and lines, which may increase the risk of wound infection.
* DVT: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to immobility and the presence of central lines.
* VAP: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Stress ulcer: The patient's critical illness may lead to stress ulceration, which could worsen the patient's condition.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent and treat any potential complications that may arise.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical condition. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, and blood pressure of 123/47 mmHg. The patient is intubated and sedated, with a respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 94%.

The patient has been diagnosed with respiratory failure, pneumonia, and effusions, and is being treated with antibiotics and ventilator support. The patient also has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and bacteremia, and is being treated with antibiotics. The patient has a funguria, and is being treated with antifungal medication.

The patient has a colonic distension, and is being treated with a rectal tube and total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The patient has diabetes mellitus (DM), and is being treated with insulin.

The patient has a number of laboratory values that are abnormal, including a white blood cell count of 14.3, hemoglobin of 8.2 g/dL, and platelet count of 396. The patient's creatinine is elevated at 1.1 mg/dL, and the patient's blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is elevated at 26 mg/dL.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications, including:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to the prolonged use of the ventilator.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is not fully treated, and the patient is at risk for developing further complications.
3. UTI: The patient's UTI is not fully treated, and the patient is at risk for developing further complications.
4. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia is not fully treated, and the patient is at risk for developing further complications.
5. Funguria: The patient's funguria is not fully treated, and the patient is at risk for developing further complications.
6. Colonic distension: The patient's colonic distension is not fully treated, and the patient is at risk for developing further complications.
7. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's DM is not fully controlled, and the patient is at risk for developing further complications.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is not fully treated, and the patient is at risk for developing further complications.

Overall, the patient is a complex and critically ill individual who requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan: 84 year old nursing home resident with dementia,
   mental retardation, initially admitted with urosepsis and with
   development of hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, fecal impaction.
   .
   # Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure:  Likely secondary to increased
   abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia / pneumonitis from
   extubation reintubation.  Continues to have secretions which will be a
   barrier to extubation.
   - continue to see WBC trending down.
   - suction secretions, which are less
   - changed to PS 14/8, PEEP weaned down to 8.  Will calculate RSBI again
   today and try SBT.
   - continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc (day 7 of 8 day course)
   (day 1: Day 1 = [**8-3**]).  Vanc changed to q24h bc vanc level of 29.
   Check vanc level.
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - continue GI decompression with NGT and rectal tube.
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   # sepsis: likely Gu source given positive UA, and patient
s history of
   urosepsis during prior ICU stay.  GI source is also likely as patient
   has distended colon, it is possible that patient becomes transiently
   bacteremic through distended bowel loops.  Pulmonary infection could
   play a role as well, but the pneumonia likely occurred during
   intubation as a result of aspiration in the long intubation process.
   - WBC continuing to trend down
   - continue fluconazole (day 8 of 14 day course) (day 1: [**8-2**])
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - f/u blood culture
   - fluid boluses prn to maintain MAP>65, CVP>[**9-1**], ScvO2 >70%
   - fu ID recs recs
   - tylenol for fever
   - culutre if spikes
   .
   # Colonic dilation: improving on imaging, stable on clinical exam. no
   evidence of a mechanical obstruction per radiology, likely related to a
   stool ball in his sigmoid colon vs. ileus. Per surgery any surgical
   intervention will likely involve a total colectomy. Per GI
   sigmoidoscopy will not be able to relieve an obstruction related to
   stool.
   -per HCP, no aggressive intervention: pursue conservative management
   -NGT and rectal tube in 30 cm for decompression
   -d/c enemas per GI
   - continue lactulose
   -continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc for 8 days (day 1: Day 1 =
   [**8-3**])
   -GI and gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] have signed off
   -electrolyte repletion
   -follow lactate
   .
   # Anemia: hct has been trending down during the past several days.
   Baseline hct 37-39. no evidence of bleeding. Could be contributed by
   dilutional effect and anemia of inflammation (anemia of chronic
   disease)
   - guaiac stool
   - transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #DM: continue glargine and sliding scale insulin.
   .
   # Neuro status: On morning rounds,not alert enough to further assess
   neuro status, but did grimace to pain in all 4 extremities.
   - re-assess neuro status when pt is more alert
   .
   #Hypothyroid - continue synthroid (now IV dose)
   .
   #h/o seizure disorder - continue dilantin, phenobarbital (IV).
   - check dilantin level
   .
   #osteoporosis - continue calcium and vitamin d
   .
   #Goals of care: Confirmed with HCP [**Name (NI) 792**] [**Name (NI) 8911**], pt is DNR. If
   medically optimized and pt is extubated, he would be DNI at that time,
   and comfort measures only if not tolerating after extubation.  Should
   he self extubate, will re-intubate.
   .
   #Anterior extraperitoneal bladder perforation: not a current active
   issue as per urology was likely a small perforation and self
   contained.  Per radiology no perforation was seen.
   -maintain foley
   -call urology if foley requires flushing
   .
   #Hypernatremia: resolved.
   -continue to monitor
   .
   #Acute renal failure
 resolved.  likely pre-renal in the setting of
   sepsis and hypotension
   - continue sepsis treatment
   - maintain BP with IVF
   -send urine lytes and urinalysis if creatinine worsens
   -renally dose meds

Summary:

The patient is a 84-year-old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation, and a history of urosepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His condition is complicated by sepsis, colonic dilation, anemia, diabetes, hypothyroidism, seizure disorder, osteoporosis, and anterior extraperitoneal bladder perforation. He has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and is receiving supportive care.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, and there is a risk of developing pneumonia, particularly given his history of aspiration and prolonged intubation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to be caused by a gastrointestinal source, and there is a risk of developing organ failure if not managed aggressively.
3. Colonic Dilation: The patient's colonic dilation is a risk factor for perforation and potential complications.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to be caused by dilutional effects and anemia of chronic disease, and there is a risk of developing bleeding complications if not managed properly.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status is a concern, and there is a risk of developing seizures, stroke, or other neurological complications.
6. Osteoporosis: The patient's osteoporosis is a risk factor for fractures, particularly in the setting of immobility and malnutrition.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's diabetes is a risk factor for developing hyperglycemic complications, particularly if not managed properly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis aggressively with broad-spectrum antibiotics and supportive care.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider tracheostomy if necessary.
3. Manage the patient's colonic dilation with conservative measures, such as NGT and rectal tube decompression, and consider surgical intervention if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusion if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider adjusting medications to manage potential neurological complications.
6. Manage the patient's osteoporosis with calcium and vitamin D supplementation and consider bisphosphonate therapy if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and adjust medications as necessary to manage hyperglycemia.

   Assessment and Plan: 84 year old nursing home resident with dementia,
   mental retardation, initially admitted with urosepsis and with
   development of hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, fecal impaction.
   .
   # Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure:  Likely secondary to increased
   abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia / pneumonitis from
   extubation reintubation.  Secretions have been barrier to extubation,
   now better.
   - WBC stable
   - suction secretions, which are less
   - increase PEEP and decr PS, try SBT and possible extubation tomorrow,
   when HCP is present
   - continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc (day 7 of 8 day course)
   (day 1: Day 1 = [**8-3**]).  Vanc changed to q24h bc vanc level of 29.
   Check vanc level.
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - continue GI decompression with NGT and rectal tube.
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   # sepsis: likely Gu source given positive UA, and patient
s history of
   urosepsis during prior ICU stay.  GI source is also likely as patient
   has distended colon, it is possible that patient becomes transiently
   bacteremic through distended bowel loops.  Pulmonary infection could
   play a role as well, but the pneumonia likely occurred during
   intubation as a result of aspiration in the long intubation process.
   - WBC continuing to trend down
   - continue fluconazole (day 8 of 14 day course) (day 1: [**8-2**])
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - f/u blood culture
   - fluid boluses prn to maintain MAP>65, CVP>[**9-1**], ScvO2 >70%
   - fu ID recs recs
   - tylenol for fever
   - culutre if spikes
   .
   # Colonic dilation: improving on imaging, stable on clinical exam. no
   evidence of a mechanical obstruction per radiology, likely related to a
   stool ball in his sigmoid colon vs. ileus. Per surgery any surgical
   intervention will likely involve a total colectomy. Per GI
   sigmoidoscopy will not be able to relieve an obstruction related to
   stool.
   -per HCP, no aggressive intervention: pursue conservative management
   -NGT and rectal tube in 30 cm for decompression
   -d/c enemas per GI
   - continue lactulose
   -continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc for 8 days (day 1: Day 1 =
   [**8-3**])
   -GI and gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] have signed off
   -electrolyte repletion
   -follow lactate
   .
   # Anemia: hct has been trending down during the past several days.
   Baseline hct 37-39. no evidence of bleeding. Could be contributed by
   dilutional effect and anemia of inflammation (anemia of chronic
   disease)
   - guaiac stool
   - transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #DM: continue glargine and sliding scale insulin.
   .
   # Neuro status: On morning rounds,not alert enough to further assess
   neuro status, but did grimace to pain in all 4 extremities.
   - re-assess neuro status when pt is more alert
   .
   #Hypothyroid - continue synthroid (now IV dose)
   .
   #h/o seizure disorder - continue dilantin, phenobarbital (IV).
   - check dilantin level
   .
   #osteoporosis - continue calcium and vitamin d
   .
   #Goals of care: Confirmed with HCP [**Name (NI) 792**] [**Name (NI) 8911**], pt is DNR. If
   medically optimized and pt is extubated, he would be DNI at that time,
   and comfort measures only if not tolerating after extubation.  Should
   he self extubate, will re-intubate.
   .
   #Anterior extraperitoneal bladder perforation: not a current active
   issue as per urology was likely a small perforation and self
   contained.  Per radiology no perforation was seen.
   -maintain foley
   -call urology if foley requires flushing
   .
   #Hypernatremia: resolved.
   -continue to monitor
   .
   #Acute renal failure
 resolved.  likely pre-renal in the setting of
   sepsis and hypotension
   - continue sepsis treatment
   - maintain BP with IVF
   -send urine lytes and urinalysis if creatinine worsens
   -renally dose meds

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation, initially admitted with urosepsis and developed hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, and fecal impaction.

The patient's current condition is stable, with:

* WBC count stable
* Suctioning of secretions improved
* PEEP increased and PS decreased, with a possible extubation attempt tomorrow
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics continued for 8 days (day 1: [**8-3**])
* GI decompression continued with NGT and rectal tube
* ID recs continued
* Fluid boluses as needed to maintain MAP>65, CVP>[**9-1**], and ScvO2 >70%

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of urosepsis and is currently being treated for sepsis. There is a risk of further complications, such as organ failure or death.
3. Colonic dilation: The patient has a distended colon, which may lead to further complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
4. Anemia: The patient's Hct has been trending down, and there is a risk of further anemia or bleeding.
5. Neuro status: The patient's neuro status is still unclear, and there is a risk of further neurological decline or seizures.
6. Hyperthyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, and there is a risk of further complications if not properly managed.
7. Osteoporosis: The patient has a history of osteoporosis, and there is a risk of further complications, such as fractures or osteoporosis-related events.

The patient's goals of care are DNR, with the possibility of becoming DNI if successfully extubated. If the patient self-extubates, they will be re-intubated.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 84-year-old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation, initially admitted with urosepsis and development of hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, and fecal impaction. The patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Respiratory Status:
	* Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure: likely secondary to increased abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia/pneumonitis from extubation reintubation.
	* Currently on AC due to tachypnea, with a goal of switching to PS and eventually extubation.
2. Sepsis:
	* Likely GU source given positive UA and patient's history of urosepsis during prior ICU stay.
	* GI source is also possible, with distended colon potentially causing transient bacteremia.
	* Pulmonary infection could play a role as well, but likely occurred during intubation as a result of aspiration.
3. Colonic Dilation:
	* Improving on imaging, stable on clinical exam, with no evidence of mechanical obstruction.
	* Likely related to stool ball in sigmoid colon vs. ileus.
4. Anemia:
	* Hct stable at 25 for several days, with baseline hct 37-39.
	* No evidence of bleeding, but could be contributed by dilutional effect and anemia of inflammation (anemia of chronic disease).
5. Neuro Status:
	* Patient not alert enough to further assess neuro status, but did grimace to pain in all 4 extremities.
	* Will re-assess neuro status when patient is more alert.
6. Other Medical Conditions:
	* DM: continue glargine and sliding scale insulin.
	* Hypothyroid: continue synthroid (now IV dose).
	* H/o seizure disorder: continue dilantin and phenobarbital (IV).
	* Osteoporosis: continue calcium and vitamin D.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: worsening hypoxemia, hypercapnia, or respiratory arrest.
2. Sepsis: progression to septic shock, multi-organ failure, or death.
3. Colonic perforation: worsening colonic dilation, perforation, or peritonitis.
4. Anemia: worsening anemia, bleeding, or organ failure.
5. Neurological deterioration: worsening neuro status, seizures, or brain death.
6. Infection: progression of pneumonia, UTI, or other infections.
7. GI complications: worsening colonic obstruction, perforation, or bleeding.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Respiratory support: AC, suction secretions, and possible switch to PS.
2. Sepsis treatment: continue fluconazole, fluid boluses, and electrolyte repletion.
3. Colonic management: continue NGT and rectal tube decompression, and consider re-imaging for interval change.
4. Anemia management: continue lactulose, and transfuse if hct <21.
5. Neuro status monitoring: re-assess neuro status when patient is more alert.
6. Other medical condition management: continue medications as prescribed.

The patient's goals of care are DNR, with a goal of extubation and DNI if medically optimized. If the patient self-extubates, they will be re-intubated.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation, who was initially admitted with urosepsis and developed hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, and fecal impaction. The patient has been in the ICU for several days and has been treated with various antibiotics, including vancomycin and cefepime, for suspected sepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 101.5°F, heart rate 100 bpm, blood pressure 149/57 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 97%.
* Respiratory support: The patient is currently on assist-control ventilation (AC) due to tachypnea, with a respiratory rate set at 20 breaths per minute and a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 32 cmH2O.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is slightly increasing, and his hemoglobin level is stable at 25%. His lactate level is 1.3 mmol/L.
* Imaging studies: The patient's chest X-ray shows increased haziness in the right lung field, and his abdominal imaging shows colonic dilation, which is improving.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure, likely secondary to increased abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia/pneumonitis from extubation reintubation.
* Sepsis, likely of gastrointestinal origin, given the patient's history of urosepsis during a prior ICU stay and the presence of yeasts in his urine culture.
* Colonic dilation, which is improving on imaging and is likely related to a stool ball in his sigmoid colon or ileus.
* Anemia, which is stable at 25% and may be contributed by dilutional effects and anemia of chronic disease.
* Hypernatremia, which has resolved.
* Acute renal failure, which has resolved and is likely pre-renal in the setting of sepsis and hypotension.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Suctioning secretions to improve respiratory function.
* Continuing antibiotics, including vancomycin and cefepime, for 8 days.
* Maintaining GI decompression with a nasogastric tube and rectal tube.
* Monitoring the patient's neuro status and re-assessing when the patient is more alert.
* Continuing thyroid replacement therapy with levothyroxine.
* Managing the patient's seizure disorder with phenobarbital and dilantin.
* Providing calcium and vitamin D supplements for osteoporosis.
* Maintaining the patient's Foley catheter and monitoring for any signs of complications.
* Continuing sepsis treatment and monitoring the patient's lactate level.
* Monitoring the patient's electrolyte levels and repleting as necessary.

The patient's goals of care are to be medically optimized and then extubated, at which point they would be do not intubate (DNI) and receive comfort measures only if not tolerating. If the patient self-extubates, they would be re-intubated.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male admitted to the ICU for hypoxemic respiratory failure with abdominal distention and likely pneumonia. The patient's condition remains unstable, with ongoing fevers and persistent respiratory failure despite a significant course of antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.5°F (38.6°C)
* Heart rate: 113 bpm
* Blood pressure: 188/73 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 35 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.1-12.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 569 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 216 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.8-1.1 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: within normal range
* Lactic acid: 1.3 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 202 IU/L

The patient's respiratory support includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL
* Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O
* FiO2 of 40%
* Respiratory system compliance (RSBI) deferred due to PEEP > 10 cmH2O and respiratory rate > 35 inspirations per minute

The patient's abdominal exam is soft, with bowel sounds present, but distended. The patient's neurologic exam is limited due to sedation, but they respond to tactile stimuli.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's persistent respiratory failure despite antibiotics and PSV support may lead to further deterioration in lung function and increased risk of respiratory arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing fevers and elevated white blood cell count may indicate ongoing sepsis, which could progress to septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal distention and elevated intra-abdominal pressure may lead to compromise of visceral perfusion and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Constipation: The patient's abdominal distention and decreased bowel sounds may indicate constipation, which could lead to bowel obstruction and further complications.
5. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's laboratory results show mild electrolyte imbalances, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications if not addressed promptly.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to continue aggressive respiratory support, antibiotics, and management of abdominal distention. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the healthcare team should focus on providing palliative care and improving the patient's quality of life.

   84 year old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation,
   initially admitted with urosepsis and with development of hypoxemic
   respiratory failure, HAP, fecal impaction.
   .
   # Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure:  Likely secondary to increased
   abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia / pneumonitis from
   extubation reintubation.  Secretions have been barrier to extubation,
   improving.
   - suction secretions, which are less
   - switched back to AC due to tachypnea on PS trial, continue current
   setting

   presence. Pt will be DNI after extubation.

   - f/u ID recs
   .

   history of urosepsis during prior ICU stay.  GI source is also likely
   as patient has distended colon, it is possible that patient becomes
   transiently bacteremic through distended bowel loops.  Pulmonary
   infection could play a role as well, but the pneumonia likely occurred
   during intubation as a result of aspiration in the long intubation
   process.
   - WBC slightly increasing

   evidence of a mechanical obstruction per radiology, likely related to a
   stool ball in his sigmoid colon vs. ileus. Per surgery any surgical
   intervention will likely involve a total colectomy. Per GI
   sigmoidoscopy will not be able to relieve an obstruction related to
   stool.

   -NGT and rectal tube in 30 cm for decompression
   -d/c enemas per GI
   - continue lactulose

   -follow lactate which has been normal
   .
   # Anemia: hct stable at 25 for several days.  Baseline hct 37-39. no

   anemia of inflammation (anemia of chronic disease)
   - guaiac stool
   - transfuse if hct <21
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 84-year-old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation, initially admitted with urosepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure, HAP, and fecal impaction. The patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Respiratory:
	* Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure, likely secondary to increased abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia/pneumonitis from extubation reintubation.
	* Patient is on mechanical ventilation, with a tidal volume of 500 mL, and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O.
2. Sepsis:
	* Patient has a positive urine culture for yeast, and a history of urosepsis during prior ICU stay.
	* Sepsis is likely of GU origin, with the possibility of transient bacteremia through distended bowel loops.
	* Patient is receiving fluconazole for 14 days, with plans to recheck urine culture upon completion of the course.
3. Colonic dilation:
	* Patient has a distended colon, with a stool ball in the sigmoid colon.
	* Conservative management is being pursued, with NGT and rectal tube decompression.
4. Anemia:
	* Patient has a stable hemoglobin level of 25%, with no evidence of bleeding.
	* Possible causes of anemia include dilutional effect and anemia of inflammation.
5. DM:
	* Patient is receiving glargine and sliding scale insulin.
6. Neuro status:
	* Patient is not alert enough to further assess neuro status, but did grimace to pain in all four extremities.
	* Neuro status will be reassessed when the patient is more alert.
7. Goals of care:
	* Patient is DNR, with plans to become DNI after extubation.
	* If the patient self-extubates, they will be re-intubated.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen, requiring further interventions such as increased oxygen support or tracheostomy.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress, leading to multi-organ failure or death.
3. Colonic perforation: The patient's distended colon may lead to a perforation, which can be life-threatening.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to fatigue, weakness, or decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's DM may lead to hyperglycemia, which can increase the risk of complications such as infections, organ damage, and mortality.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to increased risk of falls, aspiration, or other complications.
7. Osteoporosis: The patient's osteoporosis may lead to fractures, particularly in the context of immobility and malnutrition.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment plans accordingly to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old nursing home resident with dementia, mental retardation,
   initially admitted with urosepsis and with development of hypoxemic
   respiratory failure, HAP, fecal impaction.
   .
   # Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure:  Likely secondary to increased
   abdominal distention and aspiration pneumonia / pneumonitis from
   extubation reintubation.  Secretions have been barrier to extubation,
   improving.
   - suction secretions, which are less
   - switched back to AC due to tachypnea.  Repeat gas, may try weaning to
   PS.  Ultimate goal of SBT and possible extubation.
   - can d/c vanc/cefepime today, but may want to check with ID
   considering low grade fever overnight (day 8 of 8 day course) (day 1:
   Day 1 = [**8-3**]).  Considered adding fluoroquinoline and flagyl.
   - per ID d/c cipro,  can d/c flagyl as c.diff neg x 3
   - continue GI decompression with NGT and rectal tube.
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   # sepsis: likely Gu source given positive UA of yeasts, and patient
   history of urosepsis during prior ICU stay.  GI source is also likely
   as patient has distended colon, it is possible that patient becomes
   transiently bacteremic through distended bowel loops.  Pulmonary
   infection could play a role as well, but the pneumonia likely occurred
   during intubation as a result of aspiration in the long intubation
   process.
   - WBC slightly increasing
   - continue fluconazole (day 10 of 14 day course) (day 1: [**8-2**])
   - f/u blood culture
   - fluid boluses prn to maintain MAP>65, CVP>[**9-1**], ScvO2 >70%
   - fu ID recs recs
   - tylenol for fever
   - culutre if spikes
   .
   # Colonic dilation: improving on imaging, stable on clinical exam. no
   evidence of a mechanical obstruction per radiology, likely related to a
   stool ball in his sigmoid colon vs. ileus. Per surgery any surgical
   intervention will likely involve a total colectomy. Per GI
   sigmoidoscopy will not be able to relieve an obstruction related to
   stool.
   -may want to consider re-imaging today for interval change and setting
   of fever spikes
   -per HCP, no aggressive intervention: pursue conservative management
   -NGT and rectal tube in 30 cm for decompression
   -d/c enemas per GI
   - continue lactulose
   -continue broad coverage with cefepime, vanc for 8 days (day 1: Day 1 =
   [**8-3**])
   -GI and gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] have signed off
   -electrolyte repletion
   -follow lactate
   .
   # Anemia: hct stable at 25 for several days.  Baseline hct 37-39. no
   evidence of bleeding. Could be contributed by dilutional effect and
   anemia of inflammation (anemia of chronic disease)
   - guaiac stool
   - transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #DM: continue glargine and sliding scale insulin.
   .
   # Neuro status: On morning rounds,not alert enough to further assess
   neuro status, but did grimace to pain in all 4 extremities.
   - re-assess neuro status when pt is more alert
   .
   #Hypothyroid - continue synthroid (now IV dose)
   .
   #h/o seizure disorder - continue dilantin, phenobarbital (IV).
   - check dilantin level
   .
   #osteoporosis - continue calcium and vitamin d
   .
   #Goals of care: Confirmed with HCP [**Name (NI) 792**] [**Name (NI) 8911**], pt is DNR. If
   medically optimized and pt is extubated, he would be DNI at that time,
   and comfort measures only if not tolerating after extubation.  Should
   he self extubate, will re-intubate.
   .
   #Anterior extraperitoneal bladder perforation: not a current active
   issue as per urology was likely a small perforation and self
   contained.  Per radiology no perforation was seen.
   -maintain foley
   -call urology if foley requires flushing
   .
   #Hypernatremia: resolved.
   -continue to monitor
   .
   #Acute renal failure
 resolved.  likely pre-renal in the setting of
   sepsis and hypotension
   - continue sepsis treatment
   - maintain BP with IVF
   -send urine lytes and urinalysis if creatinine worsens
   -renally dose meds
   ICU Care
